node.text:
Thanks to our fantastic sponsor: @matific I am sharing essential tips for teachers to prepare for the school year! Feel free to share or ask questions and add your own tips in the comments section. For more tips, be sure to check out my new blog post in which I share additional information and ideas that will help us all start the year calm and ready to go! ~ Jen
.
.
.
 #edtech #matificb2s

node.title: Back to school tips for teachers!

node.text: I’ve been asked to show the photo books I made for the kids. These have been given as gifts somewhere along the way, usually when a new sibling was about to be welcomed into the family. I hope I’ve given enough detail, but please message if you have more questions.

node.text:
LETTER SOUND focus ❤️As promised this is the follow on learning time from the post two back in my feed. That post was in the morning, then we had recess, outdoor play, and came inside for a group time Prelit lesson (a pic of what we did is the 2nd photo- although there is a lot to it). We toured the classroom, had a very short play, then put everything aside for lunch.😅 After lunch playtime (which is very open- construction play, puzzles, reading etc- generally quiet time as they need time/space to recharge) I put everything back on tables and we explored again. Note: we had some focus on the previous week’s letter sound and often do this (revising what has come before).

As I write with everything, this worked for this particular group of children on this day. With another class I might make changes. For example my class last year had greater sensory play needs- I would have changed the ‘find the S’ trays of chickpeas to put this in the tuff tray and may have used something like shaving foam spread on mirrors instead of the colouring stencil. I don’t often use stencils but my current class has a large group that are completely obsessed with colouring in and ask for it. 

Printables used here were from a lovely colleague.

❤️Jen @living_future_memories 
🏡 @where_heart_meets_home 
🏫 @invite_to_learn @st_petersanglican

node.text:
🌾WHAT can natural loose parts be used for? And WHY? For a start: they are FREE and easily accessible. When going for a walk with a child, they will collect them quite often without even being asked! There are also endless ideas for the use of these valuable resources.

Natural loose parts will depend on your location. Options include (but are not limited to):
1️⃣Rocks
2️⃣Shells
3️⃣Dried coral
4️⃣Leaves
5️⃣Seed pods
6️⃣Sticks
7️⃣Dried flowers
8️⃣Seeds
9️⃣Pine needle pieces
🔟Branch discs (this requires a little more work).

Tell me: do you use natural loose parts? If not does this tempt you into trying using them? Double tap if you like the idea, share if you think others should try it too, and comment with any questions or ideas for loose parts you have! ❤️Jen

node.text:
Classroom tour❤️ From waaayyyy back in Term 1. I know it sounds crazy, but I’ve woken up excited that it’s only 5 weeks until I’ll be preparing for welcoming my class back onsite!✨ I am asked all the time about how my classroom changes over the day, so I’m starting with this post, then will do a follow up within the next week that shows the set up for later in the day when I had focused very specifically on literacy. As it was the second letter sound I introduced the teaching and activities were quite specifically chosen. Are you interested in seeing it?
Share if you love the tour, comment if you want to know more, or double tap if it’s helpful. ❤️Jen @living_future_memories 

Activities shown (note that they were carefully chosen for the needs of students in my class: hand strength, visual discrimination, sensory input, fine motor practice, spacial awareness, scissor skills practice etc):
1️⃣Sparkle cookies: flour, oil and sprinkles. 
2️⃣Spots: Grapat with pom poms on the hex tray. @growing.kind @modernteaching 
3️⃣Jelly digging. It was great we had 3 messy day activities left over as we had a little one who missed this special day. We made sure she had the first turn with the jelly.💕 
4️⃣Sand writing. 
5️⃣Stickers & sticky tape. My class became obsessed with paper chains after this and have become quite amazing at completely making their own, and it was great for working on patterning.
6️⃣Sparkle art. Mirrors with loose parts are amazing!
7️⃣Spaghetti snip. I remember be thrilled this day because a child who was anti scissors started to be okay with them!
8️⃣Make a muscle & band aids on children outlines. @anideaontuesday ❤️ Part of our unit of inquiry, following student questions.
9️⃣Sticks on the light table (which had an elevated square made from blocks on it.)
🔟Rainbow tower building. @thecreativetoyshop

node.text:
🔟 SMELL & TASTE sensory play ideas!👃💋 #Sensoryplay isn’t just about hands. Adding another sensory element adds to the play and learning experience.😘Jen @living_future_memories 

TEN IDEAS!
1️⃣Did you know you can use actual lavender to a sensory tray rather than using the #lavender scent added to something else?! I would love to try this with rose petals too! I will be collecting them from my garden so I know no pesticides have been used on them. 
2️⃣Invitation to taste. Wash off the top part of the plant and scissors, allowing the child to cut and taste for themselves. This is even easier in a backyard garden!In class I recorded their responses which were typed up later and added to portfolios with a photo of the experience. 
3️⃣Match the scents: #essentialoils + cotton balls + jars + pics.
4️⃣Vanilla #playdough. Amazing! Trust me!
5️⃣Blossom play!🌸 Incredible capacity #learning experience they won’t forget.
6️⃣Orange play. Slices of fruit in water are excellent for play. For one child this could then become morning tea. It’s great for having them become accustomed to fruit that aren’t their favourite.
7️⃣Sensory rice: essential oils added.
8️⃣Lavender cloud dough.
9️⃣Purchased sensory play dough. My kids adore @wilddough.co 🌹
🔟Guess the scents: essential oils on cotton balls in jars to match with the actual item. Clipboards added for drawing/recording answers. 

Double tap if you love play using all the senses! Share if you think others need to know so they can join in the fun too. Comment if you want to give one of these a go! 🎉🌸

node.text:
We are often way too hard on ourselves as parents. Sure, there are always things we can all do better. The list feels endless. BUT look at their smiles: you help make those smiles happen & you are teaching them so much about life by just living and being kind to yourself too. 

My tips?
❤️Take the toys on a mat outside and sit with tea or coffee close by so you can all enjoy the sunshine. You are a person too-you deserve rest (*talking to myself🙈). 
❤️Set up an elaborate activity if this brings you joy. Or don’t. Giving them something random with play dough is generally awesome in their eyes & you can clean the kitchen etc while they play. Eg: cars, trains, pebbles, birthday candles, little dolls, wooden toys, Duplo.
❤️Let them experiment with things that aren’t toys. We love our rock pit, and nuts & bolts are awesome (just make sure they are all the same size thread).
❤️Mud, dirt, sand, rocks, water & grass are all great for sensory play. You don’t have to make something. This is all I used (apart from play dough, blue tack & paint) until my 3rd child was 18mths (5yrs of parenting).
❤️But also, making sensory fillers can be fun & feels super rewarding when they play with it for hours.🥰
❤️Set your own boundaries as this teaches your children it’s okay for them to have boundaries as they grow. As a mum of children 5-18, 4 of whom are girls, a guiding question for me is: would I be happy for my daughters to live the life I am living? Because I’m showing them though my actions what I believe to be right.
❤️Wooden toys are beautiful, versatile & last, & yes I recommend them as great special occasion gifts. But I also don’t support going into debt to buy them. There are lots of alternatives for play that are inexpensive.
❤️As a baseline, I like to make sure that in a day there have been hugs, smiles, a story read, listening from everyone (me too), food of some kind & taking care of our home together in a small way. The rest: a bonus.
❤️Focus on what you have done with your children in a day, rather than what you didn’t do. Be encouraged that you are their safe place & that’s what matters most.

What do you find most challenging as a parent? 😘Jen (Shares are fine)

node.text:
INDEPENDENT PLAY🌈I’m asked about it often, and it was a big challenge with one of my own 6 children, so I understand! THIS post by @busytoddler is a great place to start so I have shared it.😊 I hope it helps.♥️ I’d love to hear about play in your home- does independent play happen easily? Jen 😘@living_future_memories @where_heart_meets_home 

From @busytoddler 
“Let's talk about play. We hear it over and over again, "Play is the work of childhood" (Jean Piaget) but how do we get children to that point of play? Sometimes, it's easy (I have a child like that). They just play. Sometimes, it's not so easy (I have a child like that, too) 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
TODAY ➡️ a few tips to get you started with building a culture of play in your home. It can be done. We can help our kids be successful with play, whether they are an only child or one of many.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Remember, play is a skill ✨ Just like you wouldn't expect to walk outside tomorrow and run a marathon, we can't expect kids to magically sit and play for hours if that isn't a skill they've been learning.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We build this skill bit by bit. Minute by minute and in small chunks.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Start with these 5 tips ➡️
1️⃣Set a predictable schedule for the day that includes play times (I use these times to do some of my work).
2️⃣Hear your child playing? DO NOT INTERUPT. It's like entering a conversation mid-way or cutting into a train of thought. Chat with them later if you're curious.
3️⃣Let them have their space without hovering or feeling like they're being watched. You can still supervise but give room.
4️⃣Check that they can be successful with their toys and are able to find what they need to play. This might mean doing a toy purge and putting away some unused or not-ready-for items.
5️⃣Show them how much you value play. It's easy for play to come off as a chore instead of the beautiful, rich, and deep learning experience we know it is. Be honest with your kids about play and let them know how important it is for their growth and development.”

May be an image of text that says 'Need More Independent Play? TRY THESE 5 TIPS MAKE IT ROUTINE: Have set times each day where kids are expected to play 1 2 DON'T INTERRUPT: Avoid the temptation to ask questions while they're playing GIVE THEM SPACE: No one likes to be hovered over. Supervise from a (safe) distance 3 4 MAKE PLAY DOABLE: Leave out toys and supplies they can use without adult help VALUE PLAY: Make sure kids know you value their play work 5 BUSYTODDLER'.

Photo by Jen~Where Learning Meets Play on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says '1 HAVE A PLAY ROUTINE Instead of play being a random occurrence or only when you need a break, set up spe times each day as play times, just like you may do for soccer practice or homework. This helps kids get into a play routine and know the expectation. BUSYTOER'.

Photo by Jen~Where Learning Meets Play on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says '2 AVOID INTERRUPTING If you see your child playing or self- entertaining, don't break their concentration by asking questions. Give them space to work. Touch base later if you want to find out more about their play. BUSY 4TODDLER'.

Photo by Jen~Where Learning Meets Play on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says '3 GIVE THEM SPACE Play is hard work, and kids need breathing room. It really bugs me when someone hovers and reads what I'm writing as type it... it's the same for kids and play. Supervise from a safe distance. BUSYTODDLER'.

Photo by Jen~Where Learning Meets Play on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'MAKE PLAY DOABLE Kids need to be able to find the right tools for their play and to use those tools without adult assistance: Spend some time auditing toys. Donate unused or outgrown items. Recycle broken toys or toys with missing parts. Put away (for now) toys that your child can only use with assistance. BUSYTODDLER'.

Photo by Jen~Where Learning Meets Play on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says '5 VALUE PLAY It's easy to accidentally make play sound like a chore or dismissive "Just go play!" Instead, show your child how much you value their play and the important learning they do when playing. Talk about how play is their job. Instill in them a deep respect for the importance of play- and model that with how you frame and talk about play at home. Don't let play be an afterthought. BUSY 4TODDLER'.

node.text:
Peek into my classroom❤️ Can you see how I’ve balanced the activities available, responding to my students’ needs, for this play session? This is all intentional and I spend considerable time monitoring & planning to make this happen. 

So many of you are interested in ways to encourage writing- on this particular day there were 3 different activities that made writing fun. I will add a few ‘in use’ photos to stories to help you see how this space is used (without student faces as I only show those photos on our official school early learning account @invite_to_learn ♥️).

I will share more pre/early writing ideas soon, but it would be helpful to know: where is your child/ren currently up to and what challenges are you having? 

Questions are welcome and shares appreciated. Jen 😘 @living_future_memories @where_heart_meets_home {PS: I am counting down the days to be back teaching in this space!✨🥰}

node.text:
Repost from a post I wrote over on @invite_to_learn ❤️ Let’s start with realistic expectations. A 3 yr old should not be expected to be a 5 yr old. As with every single thing I ever post- consider the actual child in front of you: where are they really at, what do they need, how can I help them right now. And number one- how can I connect with this child? Because connection, understanding and to be heard, is often what we all want, at 5 or 55. Having the knowledge of what is realistic & research based practices, is helpful in guiding us to care for our little ones and provide valuable learning experiences. ❤️Jen @living_future_memories 
.
.
@invite_to_learn Repost:
P R E W R I T I N G patterns 🌈 This is a repost from @perthchildrensot that I thought might be valuable for parents. Remember: these are averages and earlier isn’t necessary better. In Prep we respond to exactly where the child is currently at and prepare appropriate learning experiences in response. We are constantly reviewing and making changes so that students learn in context. This is important as we want genuine learning, so it has to be relevant and hold meaning to the child.
.
.
“These are ‘prewriting patterns’, with the average (not prescribed) age at which children are developmentally ready to achieve these patterns listed below them in years and months. Being able to process visual information and produce a movement in response (e.g. copying these prewriting patterns or letter formations), is known as ‘visual motor integration’....... Source: Beery Buktenica Test of Visual Motor Integration, 6th Edition.”
⠀
⠀
#visualmotorintegration #letterformations #prewriting #writing #kindergarten #schoolreadiness #letthembelittle #letthemplay #prewritingskills #invitetolearn #phonologicalawareness #earlyliteracyskills #literacy #earlychildhoodeducation #earlyyears #earlylearning #earlyyearseducation #educationmatters #invitationtolearn #playbasedlearning #learningthroughplay #prek #prekteacher #kindergartenteacher #iteachprek #iteachkindergarten #playmatters #

node.text:
Craft box 🌈 This is one way I’ve been getting hours of work done at home with hubby at work, a preschooler at home (and a few other kids remote learning in the mix💁‍♀️😜😅). 

We have two different craft boxes. Giving Libby the choice between the two saves my day often! Having her feel she has an element of control over her day is most certainly needed. 

You can fill a craft box with anything you choose: leaves, pressed flowers, cut up card from packaging are all completely free choices that we have used in the past. Painting the cardboard packaging and cutting it up is an activity in itself! I’ve done this with children often.

Right now I’m all about the able-to-be-purchased BIG draw card items, as me being in 5 Zoom classes/meetings in a day won’t happen if my children are not entertained.😅 Libby can be a HUGE distraction for her siblings if not kept super busy because they adore her and usually drop everything to play whenever she wants them to. #youngestchildlife

Do you have a craft box? What’s your fav craft box items? Jen @living_future_memories @where_heart_meets_home

node.text: Looking for a bit of control in the chaos? Decanting paint into sauce bottles really helps.😂 #10yearsgoingstrong👊 At least it does for me! There is something really satisfying about seeing them all lined up full in the cabinet. It may be a small success, but sometimes that’s EXACTLY what I need. PLUS: painting will be a snap to get ready for the next month. Got to LOVE that!! #timesaver 🙌Decanting paint into easy squeeze bottles: yes or no?? Jen @living_future_memories ❤️@where_heart_meets_home 🏡

node.text:
Making it through the day, one old-encouraging-photo at a time.😅 My house will look so much better when 8 people aren’t constantly in it.😂 My tribe are counting down the days until lockdown ends (will it ever?!!) and we can all return to school. To quote one of my teens: “I love people! I’d just like some different ones right now.” I love insta beautiful photos as I find them so calming! Such an escape for me! Some people say it makes them feel bad. What about you? Inspiring/calming or blah? 
❤️Jen @living_future_memories @where_heart_meets_home

node.text:
Flower name/words 💜💚 Did you know that the seasons DO NOT change on the same date in all the countries around the world?! I learned something new this week. In Australia our seasons are based on the months of the year: Summer starts 1st December, Autumn (not Fall here😉) starts 1st March, Winter starts 1st June, Spring 1st September. This doesn’t include the Northern Territory in Australia which has different seasons. In the US the seasons start on different days!! I never knew this! What are the arrangement of the seasons where you live? Tell us! Jen x ❤️ @living_future_memories 🏡 @where_heart_meets_home 🏫 @invite_to_learn @st_petersanglican 

{Activity shown is great for early literacy used with letters, words, or for numeracy with numbers, and great for fine motor development. Questions and shares welcome.😊}
